Several dogs didn’t have water available at the time of inspection. The inspection started at 11:45 am. In the whelping
portion of the sheltered building there were 4 female dogs with litters; including one female dog with a litter of three
puppies; two female dogs each with a litter of two puppies; and one female dog with one puppy. All the enclosures had
water bowls, but they were dry. The licensee stated that he has a worker that comes and does evening chores at night
and probably left around 6pm the night before and he hadn’t been out yet this morning. The licensee provided water for
the four female dogs at the time of inspection; However, upon providing the dogs with water, one adult black and white
female Shih Tzu, microchip # 956000010767846, approximately 4 years old drank continuously for approximately 1
minute and 12 seconds. During this time one of her two puppies hovered over her trying to get a drink for itself. Failure to
provide continuous potable water may result in severe dehydration which could have a detrimental impact on the health of
the animal. Potable water must be continuously available for dogs. The licensee must ensure that each dog is provided
with potable water at all times in order to support their health and well-being. To be corrected: from this point forward on
3/17/2023.
Note: The licensee provided each of the female dogs with water in their enclosure at the time of the inspection
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End Section
